abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Drainage V Project in the Arab Republic
            of Egypt. The objectives of the project were: (i) to
            increase agricultural productivity by providing adequate
            drainage infrastructure; (ii) to evacuate excess water and
            salt out of the production areas, and hence reverse the
            deterioration of the land resource base; and (iii) to
            strengthen the Egyptian Public Authority for Drainage
            Projects (EPADP) for the design, construction supervision
            and management of drainage activities, with particular
            emphasis on improvement of monitoring and evaluation
            (M&E) and maintenance of the improved drainage
            facilities. EPADP performance was highly satisfactory in
            design, investigations and implementation; it fully complied
            with all the legal covenants related to annual reviews,
            staffing and budgetary provisions. The performance of the
            World Bank is considered satisfactory throughout. The
            following are the major lessons learned: (i) Technical
            assistance and training requirements, if not provided
            through Bank financing, must be agreed to in detail between
            the Borrower and Co-financiers before project negotiations;
            (ii) Strict enforcement of conditions defined in contract
            documents, particularly those relating to completion of
            works and cancellation of contracts including forfeiture of
            performance bonds, should be adhered to by Borrower; (iii)
            Civil works contractors should be pre-qualified to eliminate
            those who cannot perform well or have a troubled
            contracting; (iv) Well-defined monitoring indicators,
            particularly those related to impact analysis must be
            prepared at appraisal and periodic reviews of such
            indicators should take place during project supervision; and
            (v) Project supervision missions should have included in
            addition to the engineer, M&E specialist, etc., an
            agriculturist who could have followed up on the
            project's impact on agricultural production.
